chapter: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question: Question 1: What is the most powerful activator of sympathetic vasomotor system?

options.a: Posture of the body against gravity

questions.explanation:
The most powerful activator of the sympathetic vasomotor system is CNS ischemic response. CNS ischemic response: When blood flow to the vasomotor center in lower brainstem (medulla) is severely decreased, the 
local concentration of CO2 increases greatly and has a potent effect in stimulating the sympathetic 
vasomotor nervous control areas in the brain’s medulla. Blood pressure may increase till 250 
mmHg. The strong activation may cause some peripheral vessels to occlude. It doesnt activate till arterial pressure drops to 60mmHg or less, hence it is principally a 
emergency mechanism. Note: Baroreceptors are the most common activators, but not the most powerful.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question:
Question 2: During exercise, the organ experiencing the smallest decrease in blood flow is 
.
questions.explanation:
During exercise, the organ experiencing the smallest decrease in blood flow is brain. 489 
Sold by @itachibot During exercise, the coronary and cerebral systems, are spared of vasoconstrictor effect because 
both these circulatory areas have poor vasoconstrictor innervation .
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question:
Question 3: An elderly man, with congestive cardiac failure, complains of shortness of breath when lying 
down. What is the mechanism behind this symptom?

options.b: Reservoir function of veins in lower limbs.

questions.explanation:
The given scenario describes orthopnea in congestive heart failure. It is due to reservoir function 
of pulmonary veins. Orthopnea is dyspnea occurring in the recumbent position. It results from redistribution of fluid from the splanchnic circulation and lower extremities 
(increased venous return) into the heart during recumbency. This increased venous return is not 
put out by the left ventricle and hence pools in the pulmonary veins that acts as capacitance 
vessels (reservoir function) adding to the already congested pulmonary vasculature resulting in 
breathing difficulty.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question:
Question 4: The interstitial fluid pressure is negative in  
.
questions.explanation:
The interstitial fluid pressure is negative in the lungs. The interstitial fluid pressure is slightly negative in the body except in the encapsulated organs. It is positive in • Rigid closed compartments- bone marrow, brain • Encapsulated organs - kidney, skeletal muscle This is due to the fact that in the kidneys, high-pressure vessels push the interstitial fluid against 
an unyielding fibrous capsule raising the pressure. The same principle applies to skeletal muscle 
surrounded by layers of fascia.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question: Question 5: Blood flow per minute in pulmonary circulation is

options.a: Less than flow through systemic circulation
options.b: More than flow through systemic circulation
options.c: Equal to flow through systemic circulation

questions.explanation:
Blood flow per minute in the pulmonary circulation is equal to flow through the systemic 
circulation so as to provide continuous blood supply to the body. If the flow rate is slower in the pulmonary circulation than systemic, then the left ventricle would 
soon empty completely. If the flow rate is faster in the pulmonary circulation then the left 
ventricle would be soon overloaded. Please note that because some blood flows into the bronchial arteries, the actual flow through the 
pulmonary circulation is slightly lesser than the flow through the systemic circulation. However, 
this question aims to state that the blood flow through both pulmonary and systemic circulation is 
largely equal. 490 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question:
Question 6: A patient was receiving a red cell transfusion following hip arthroplasty. Midway through the 
transfusion, she developed signs and symptoms of shock. What is the type of shock seen in 
her?
questions.explanation:
The shock due to a transfusion reaction is distributive shock. During transfusion reaction, there is decreased systemic vascular resistance due to system-wide 
vasodilation mediated by release of histamine by mast cells in response to antigen bound IgE, 
leading to distributive shock. Types of circulatory shock: • Hypovolemic shock: due to decreased blood in vascular compartment. E.g., haemorrhage, 
dehydration. • Cardiogenic shock: due to decreased capacity of heart to pump. E.g., any pathology of heart 
decreasing its ability to maintain cardiac output. • Obstructive shock: due to conditions causing obstruction to blood flow in lungs and 
heart.E.g:pulmonary embolism. • Distributive/vasculogenic shock: excessive vasodilation leading to impaired organ perfusion. E.g: 
septic shock, SIRS, transfusion reaction, Addisonian crisis, neurogenic shock. Three stages of shock: • Non-progressive: also called compensated shock, where normal compensatory mechanism 
eventually causes full recovery without help from outside therapy. • Progressive: also called non-compensated, without therapy it gets steadily worse. • Irreversible: even therapy is inadequate to save life.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question:
Question 7: During foetal life, blood vessel with maximum concentration of oxygen is  
.
questions.explanation:
During fetal life, blood vessel with maximum concentration of oxygen is umblical vein. 491 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question:
Question 8: Progressive hemorrhagic shock is characterized by  
.

options.a: Blood clots in the small blood vessels

questions.explanation:
Progressive hemorrhagic shock is characterized by the presence of blood clots in the small blood 
vessels. The initiating cause of this blockage is sluggish blood flow in the microvessels. Tissue metabolites 
plus other deterioration products from the ischemic tissues causes minute clots in these vessels. 
Thus the microvasculature gets blocked by the sludged blood. In progressive hemorrhagic shock, there is increased lysosomal activity, decreased active 
transport of sodium and tissue acidosis.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question:
Question 9: During rest, blood flow through skeletal muscle averages  
.
questions.explanation:
During rest, blood flow through skeletal muscle averages 3–4 mL/min/100 g of muscle. The resting blood flow through various organs in a 63 kg adult man with a mean arterial pressure 
90 mmHg and O2 consumption 250 mL/min is given below. Region 
Blood flow (ml/mi 
n) Liver 
1500 Kidneys 
1260 Brain 
750 840 Skeletal musc 
le 250 Heart muscle 
s
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question:
Question 10: The type of shock that has high cardiac output is  
.
questions.explanation:
Septic shock is characterized by high cardiac output. High cardiac output in septic shock is caused by • arteriolar dilation in the infected tissues and • high metabolic rate and vasodilation (resulting from bacterial toxin stimulating cellular 
metabolism and from high body temperature).
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question:
Question 11: Thin-walled and delicate vessels like capillaries are less prone to rupture. This can be 
explained by  
.
questions.explanation:
Thin-walled and delicate vessels like capillaries are less prone to rupture and this can be explained 
by Laplace law. 492 
Sold by @itachibot The principal reason for these vessels' relative invulnerability is their small diameter. The 
protective effect of small size, in this case, is an example of the law of Laplace. Laplace law states that tension in the wall of a cylinder (T) is equal to the product of the 
transmural pressure (P) and the radius (r) divided by the wall thickness (w): T = Pr/w As the tissue pressure is low, P is equated to the pressure inside the blood vessel. W can be ignored as well as capillaries are thin walled. Hence: P = T/r In a thin-walled viscus, P = T divided by the two principal radii of curvature of the viscus: P = T 
(1/r1+1/r2) In a cylinder such as a blood vessel, one radius is infinite, so P = T /r Hence, smaller the radius, lower is the tension necessary in the wall to balance the distending 
pressure.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question:
Question 12: The relationship between the flow in a long narrow tube, the viscosity of the fluid, and the 
radius of the tube is expressed mathematically by 
. 485 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The relationship between the flow in a long narrow tube, the viscosity of the fluid, and the radius 
of the tube is expressed mathematically by Poiseullie's law. where F = flow PA  PB = pressure difference between two ends of the tube  = viscosity r = radius of tube L = length of tube 493 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question:
Question 13: In the 2 vessels shown below, assume the pressure along both the vessels is the same and 
both follow linear flow pattern. What will be the amount of blood flow in A compared to B
questions.explanation:
The relationship between the flow in a long narrow tube, the viscosity of the fluid, and the radius 
of the tube is expressed mathematically in the formula called as Poiseuille's law : Blood flow (F) inside the vessel depends on: • Pressure difference: directly proportional • Viscosity: inversely proportional • Radius: directly proportional to the fourth power • Length of the vessel: inversely proportional Here, the radius is doubled so the flow increases by 2 to the power of 4 = 16. the length of the vessel is also doubled, so the flow decreases by half (÷2) = 8
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question:
Question 14: Which of the following statements is false about Cuthbertson's metabolic ebb and flow 
responses to trauma?

options.a: The "ebb" phase is associated with a decline in body temperature and oxygen consumption.
options.b: The "flow" phase occurs after resuscitation from a state of shock.
options.c: The "ebb" phase is aimed at reducing posttraumatic energy depletion.
options.d: The "ebb" phase leads to activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic

questions.explanation:
The "flow" phase (not "ebb") leads to activation of the innate immune system and induction of the 
hepatic acute-phase response. Cuthbertson's ebb and flow response to trauma: The "ebb" phase lasts for a brief duration and is associated with a decline in body temperature and 
oxygen consumption, aimed at reducing post traumatic energy depletion. The "flow" phase occurs after resuscitation from a state of shock, which leads to an increased 
metabolic turnover, activation of the innate immune system and induction of the hepatic 
acute-phase response. This hypercatabolic condition leads to a significantly increased oxygen 
consumption and energy expenditure. 494 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question:
Question 15: Hering's nerve finally relays in  
.
questions.explanation:
The Hering's nerve terminates in the medulla (Tractus solitarius). Baroreceptor reflexes • Carotid baroreceptors  Hering's nerve  the glossopharyngeal nerve  Tractus solitarius in 
medulla. • Aortic baroreceptors  Vagus nerve  tractus solitarius in medulla
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question:
Question 16: Microcirculation consists of 
.
questions.explanation: Microcirculation consists of capillaries, arterioles , venules and terminal lymphatics.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question:
Question 17: Mayer waves are due to  
.

options.a: Variation of arterial pressure during each systole.
options.b: Variation of arterial pressure due to reflex changes in nervous control of blood pressure
options.c: Variation of arterial pressure with changes in respiration.
options.d: Variation of arterial pressure with postural change.

questions.explanation:
Mayer waves are due to the variation of arterial pressure due to reflex changes in nervous control 
of blood pressure. The most important mechanisms are as follows: I: Baroreceptor and chemoreceptor reflex: High pressure excites the baroreceptors -->inhibits sympathetic nervous system and lowers the 
pressure -->The decreased pressure, in turn, reduces the baroreceptor stimulation 
-->elevating the pressure to a high value (the response is not instantaneous, it is delayed until a 
few seconds later). This high pressure then initiates another cycle, and the oscillation continues. II: Oscillation of the CNS Ischemic Response: 495 
Sold by @itachibot The cerebrospinal fluid pressure is raised to 160 mm Hg --> causes compression of cerebral 
blood vessels --> cerebral ischemia--> CNS ischemic pressure response raises the arterial 
pressure up to 200mm Hg -->the brain ischemia is relieved and the sympathetic nervous 
system becomes inactive -->the arterial pressure falls rapidly back to a much lower value, 
causing brain ischemia once again -->initiates another rise in pressure. This chain of events 
repeats itself cyclically as long as the cerebrospinal fluid pressure remains elevated.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question:
Question 18: Vasomotion refers to  
.

options.a: Venous drainage to RA by contraction of IVC.
options.b: Intermittent contraction of meta arterioles and precapillary sphincter.
options.c: Pulsatile action of arteries which help in lymphatic drainage.
options.d: Systolic pumping of blood by heart in to aorta.

questions.explanation:
Vasomotion means intermittent contraction of meta arterioles and precapillary spinchter. Blood usually does not flow continuously through the capillaries. Instead, it flows intermittently, 
turning on and off every few seconds or minutes. This is vasomotion, which is responsible for flow 
of blood in capillaries . The main regulatory factor for vasomotion is tissue oxygen concentration.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question:
Question 19: Ejection fraction in resting healthy man is approximately 
.
questions.explanation:
Ejection fraction in resting healthy man is approximately 0.6. The fraction of the end-diastolic volume that is ejected is called the ejection fraction, usually equal 
to about 60 %.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question: Question 20: The relation between ventricular stroke volume and end-diastolic volume is explained by
questions.explanation:
496 
Sold by @itachibot The relation between ventricular stroke volume and end-diastolic volume is explained by Frank 
Starling's law. Length–tension relationship in cardiac muscle is similar to that in skeletal muscle. when the 
muscle is stretched, the developed tension increases to a maximum and then declines as stretch 
becomes more extreme. Starling stated that “energy of contraction is proportional to the initial 
length of the cardiac muscle fibre”. When cardiac output is regulated by changes in cardiac fibre length, this is referred to as 
heterometric regulation. Conversely, regulation due to changes in contractility independent of length is called homometric 
regulation.
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II

questions.question:
Question 21: The best index of preload is  
.
questions.explanation:
The best index of preload is left ventricular end diastolic volume. Preload - load that the left ventricle carries before the systole. Left ventricular end diastolic volume - blood remaining at the end of diastole, which determines 
stretch of the ventricle and thus force of contraction as explained by frank starlings law. 497 
Sold by @itachibot Cardiac Cycle and Cardiac Output
questions.chapter_heading: Vascular System and Regional Circulation II
